explanation: The report is correct. OS_strnlen is implemented as a thin wrapper around memchr(s, 0, maxlen). OS_TranslatePath calls OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN) while only checking that VirtualPath != NULL (OS_CHECK_POINTER). There is no guarantee in the code that the object referenced by VirtualPath is at least OS_MAX_PATH_LEN bytes long or contains a '\0' within that many bytes. Therefore memchr may read up to OS_MAX_PATH_LEN bytes past the start of VirtualPath and can read beyond the bounds of the object (e.g. if the caller passes a small non-terminated buffer or a pointer into a smaller object). The same class of problem exists for the later call memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) where name_ptr is derived from VirtualPath. This exactly matches the concern of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (string.h functions must not cause accesses beyond object bounds). To fix this, the code must ensure the object is known to be at least maxlen bytes (or documentation+caller contract must guarantee it and be enforced), or change the API to accept an explicit buffer length and use that bound when calling memchr/strnlen, or otherwise restructure the code so all string.h calls are provably bounded within the referring object.
